googleSheetEarlyVotingDataRow.earlyVotingNotesCombined:
* Beginning Oct. 13, three weeks before the election, every work day between Oct. 13 and Election Day, and every Saturday for at least four hours, every county clerk will provide a location for safe in-person voting.
* Early voting is not absentee voting – anyone can vote early for any reason.
googleSheetEarlyVotingDataRow.vbmAbsenteeBallotRules:
* You must provide an excuse to vote by mail in Kentucky, but 100% of voters can use COVID-19 as an excuse.
* If you are requesting a ballot due to COVID-19 concerns, you must use the "Not Able to Appear at the polls on election day on account of age, disability or illness" excuse on the absentee ballot application.
* All voters may vote early without an excuse.
googleSheetEarlyVotingDataRow.idRequirementsOvr: You will need a Social Security number to use Kentucky's online voter registration system. If you do not have a Social Security number, you can still register to vote by mail or in person.
googleSheetEarlyVotingDataRow.idRequirementsSdr: Bring your Kentucky driver's license or state ID card with you. If you don't have one, bring ONE photo ID that shows your name, and ONE document that shows your name and current address.  Acceptable documents include a utility bill, bank statement, paycheck, residential lease, or any government document that shows your name and address.
googleSheetEarlyVotingDataRow.registrationRules:
To register in Kentucky you must:

  * be a citizen of the United States
  * be a resident of Kentucky for at least 28 days before to Election Day
  * be 18 years of age on or before the next general election
  * not be a convicted felon or if you have been convicted of a felony, your civil rights must have been restored by executive pardon
  * not have been judged mentally incompetent in a court of law
  * not claim the right to vote anywhere outside Kentucky
googleSheetEarlyVotingDataRow.earlyVotingByMailInfoCombined:
* Beginning Oct. 13, three weeks before the election, every work day between Oct. 13 and Election Day, and every Saturday for at least four hours, every county clerk will provide a location for safe in-person voting.
* Early voting is not absentee voting – anyone can vote early for any reason.
